sect1.title: Standard Filter Classes
sect1.para: Zend Framework comes with a standard set of filters, which are ready for you to use.

sect2.title: Alnum
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, removing all but alphabetic and digit characters. This filter includes an option to also allow white space characters.

note.para: The alphabetic characters mean characters that makes up words in each language. However, the english alphabet is treated as the alphabetic characters in following languages: Chinese, Japanese, Korean. The language is specified by Zend_Locale.

sect2.title: Alpha
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, removing all but alphabetic characters. This filter includes an option to also allow white space characters.

sect2.title: BaseName
sect2.para: Given a string containing a path to a file, this filter will return the base name of the file

sect2.title: Digits
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, removing all but digit characters.

sect2.title: Dir
sect2.para: Returns directory name component of path.

sect2.title: HtmlEntities
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, converting characters to their corresponding HTML entity equivalents where they exist.

sect2.title: StripNewlines
sect2.para: Returns the string $value without any newline control characters.

sect2.title: StringToLower
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, converting alphabetic characters to lowercase as necessary.

sect2.title: StringToUpper
sect2.para: Returns the string $value, converting alphabetic characters to uppercase as necessary.

sect2.title: StringTrim
sect2.para: Returns the string $value with characters stripped from the beginning and end.

sect2.title: StripTags
sect2.para: This filter returns the input string, with all HTML and PHP tags stripped from it, except those that have been explicitly allowed. In addition to the ability to specify which tags are allowed, developers can specify which attributes are allowed across all allowed tags and for specific tags only. Finally, this filter offers control over whether comments (e.g., <!-- ... -->) are removed or allowed.
